name: Buenos Aires
overview:
Buenos Aires (Ciudad Autónoma de Buenos Aires; CABA) is Argentina's capital and largest city. Located on the country’s eastern coast along the western banks of the estuary of the Río de la Plata, the sprawling metropolis extends to encompass the autonomous city of Buenos Aires and 24 adjacent municipalities, or partidos. Buenos Aires serves as Argentina’s industrial and financial centre and also boasts a rich historic and cultural heritage.

By South American standards, rates of violent crime are moderate but rising, and incidents of petty and street crime are common, especially in areas where tourists congregate. With a long history of social agitation and economic strife, protests and strikes are common in Buenos Aires and can escalate to violence.

Police, Ambulance, Fire (emergency): 911
Police (local): 101
Tourist Police: +54 911 5050 3293/9260 or 155 5050 9260/3293
Fire: 100
Medical: 107
arrival:
International Airport: Ministro Pistarini International Airport (EZE/SAEZ), also known as Ezeiza International Airport, is located in the Greater Buenos Aires municipality of Ezeiza, 22km (14 miles) south-southwest of central Buenos Aires. Serving as a hub for Aerolíneas Argentinas and LATAM Argentina, the airport connects the capital with dozens of regional, international and domestic destinations.

The facility is publicly owned and managed by Aeropuertos Argentina 2000.

Address: Autopista Tte Gral. Ricchieri Km 33,5, 1802 Ezeiza, Buenos Aires, Argentina
Tel: +54 11 5480-6111
Web: https://www.aa2000.com.ar/ezeiza

EZE by car
The airport is easily accessible by following the airport signs along the Autopista Tte Gral. Ricchieri highway.

EZE by coach
Safe and efficient shuttle and coach buses operate between the airport and central Buenos Aires. While the coach service runs between the airport terminals and its central station, private shuttles and hotel shuttles can pick passengers up and drop off from any address. Public bus line 394 also connects the airport to the Monte Grande Railroad Station, and public minibus line 51 to Constitución, and line 8 to La Boca.. Manuel Tienda Leon Shuttle also provides service to Terminal Madero in the city centre, and between EZE and Jorge Newbery Airfield.

EZE by taxi
Official and licenced taxi companies operate on a pre-paid basis outside the arrivals hall; taxi booths are located on either side of the receiving area of the airport. For travellers unfamiliar with Buenos Aires, it is not recommended to hail a taxi off the curb outside the airport.

Jorge Newbery Airfield (AEP/SABE; Aeroparque Jorge Newbery) is located in the Palermo neighbourhood, two kilometres (1.2 miles) northeast of downtown Buenos Aires. The AEP serves as the main hub for domestic flights in Argentina, and it serves international flights to Uruguay.

The facility is publicly owned and managed by Aeropuertos Argentina 2000.

Address: Av. Costanera Rafael Obligado s/n, C1425 CABA
Tel: +54 11 5480-6111
Web: https://www.aa2000.com.ar/aeroparque

AEP by car
The airport is easily accessible by following the airport signs along the Avenida Sarmiento, Avenida Leopoldo Lugones and Avenida Costanera Rafael Obligado.

AEP by coach
Safe and efficient shuttle and coach buses operate between the airport and central Buenos Aires. While the coach service runs between the airport terminals and its central station, private shuttles and hotel shuttles can pick passengers up and drop off from any address. Public bus line 33, 37, 45 and 160 also connects the airport to central parts of the city. Manuel Tienda Leon Shuttle also provides service between AEP and Ezeiza International Airport.

AEP by taxi
Official and licenced taxi companies operate on a pre-paid basis outside the arrivals hall; taxi booths are located outside the Sector A of the airport. For travellers unfamiliar with Buenos Aires, it is not recommended to hail a taxi off the curb outside the airport.

Visas: Visas are not required for citizens of most EU/EEA countries and those from Annex II countries, including Canada, USA, Australia, New Zealand, Brazil, Mexico and Japan, for stays of less than 90 days. Foreign nationals planning to be in Argentina for more than 90 days, or who expect to draw official attention because of their business ventures, should obtain valid business visas. Application for a business visa requires a letter from the traveller’s employer stating the business reason for travel, the anticipated length of the visit, and acceptance of financial responsibility for the traveller. Citizens of other countries should check visa requirements with the Argentinian embassy in their home country before departing for Argentina.
getting_around:
Driving

- Road Conditions: Very good
- Uniform Road Traffic Flow: right-hand traffic (RHT)
- Speed Limits (General): 40kph (25mph) within city limits and up to 120kph (74mph) on motorways
- Foreign Driver's Licences: Accepted provided come with a photo ID and are accompanied with a valid international driving permit (IDP).
- Notes: Roadways are often congested and even worse so during rush hour. Traffic laws are not always obeyed so you should not rely on other drivers to act predictably.

Public Transport

Boats/Ferries: International ferry services link Buenos Aires with Colonia and Montevideo in Uruguay. These services are fairly safe and run efficiently. However, as a general precaution it is best to never board a vessel that appears in a poor state of repair, is overcrowded, or does not have the necessary safety equipment.

Buses: Buenos Aires offers a good bus network covering most of the city. Services are inexpensive and efficient, although can become crowded at peak times. Night services are also offered, although run less than during the day. Buses operate through main Metrobus corridors as well as independently through the city. The seven Metrobus routes, with separate highway and road lanes, include the lines 9 de Julio, El Bajo, Juan Bautista Justo, San Martín, 25 de Mayo, Northern line and the Southern line. Outside of the Metrobus routes the network of regular buses is vast, but poorly organised and timetables are not tightly followed or even displayed at the majority of bus stops. To search bus connections visit the Omnilineas website.

Although accidents are not common, bus drivers tend to operate at excessive speeds leading to safety concerns. Always ensure your valuables are kept in a secured pocket as petty theft is common during busy times and drunken rowdiness can be problematic on nighttime routes. Metrobus bus stops in suburban areas are a frequent target for thieves and muggers, especially in the Liniers area at the end of the Juan Bautista Justo line and in Villa Lugano on the Southern line.

Metro: The metro system, or subte as it is locally known, is clean, and while the network is not overly large, the serve is efficient and relatively inexpensive. Trains run between 05:00 to 22:00-23:00 Monday to Saturday, and 08:00 to 22:00 on Sundays and holidays. Note that carriages become very crowded during peak hours. Petty crime and occasional muggings take place in metro stations, particularly after dark. Avoid walking alone in metro stations at night and ensure your valuables are in secure pockets close to your body.

Taxis: Official metered taxis (black-and-yellow painted vehicles) are widely available throughout the city and relatively inexpensive. While the majority of drivers are honest and helpful, taxi licensing is not strictly enforced; taxi-driver scams and express-kidnappings are on the rise in Buenos Aires. For safety reasons, radio taxis are recommended. Always ensure the metre is turned on before setting off and use small bills or near to exact change when possible.

Trains: A commuter-train system connects Buenos Aires with its outlying suburbs and neighbouring provinces. Not all lines all trains function equally; some routes offering very good services, while others use older rolling stock and journey times lengthy. Nonetheless, the train system provides a good mode of public transport to reach areas further afield where the metro leaves off.

Self-Drive: Only confident drivers should consider driving themselves around the city owing to its congestion problems, erratic driving styles and complex road system. An international driving licence is recommended. Organised gangs on motorcycles loiter around vehicles at traffic lights and do not hesitate to break a window go seize visible valuables. Always lock your windows and doors while stopped at a red traffic light and do not leave anything valuable on the passenger seat or on any other visible area in the vehicle; ideally belongings are best kept out of sight under a seat. Nueva Pompeya, Villa Soldati, Palermo and Flores are districts frequently targeted by armed robberies (piratería del asfalto) of trucks and vehicles that transport goods. Such attacks occur usually during daylight and the city averages upwards of 50 armed robberies city per month.
safety:
Violent crime is prevalent in Buenos Aires, but mainly occurs during night-time hours or in low-income districts. San Telmo, Palermo, La Boca, Recoleta and Constitución and the Greater Buenos Aires area (Vicente López, Olivos, Martinez, Acassuso, San Martín, Villa La Cárcova, San Isidro and towards the north of Buenos Aires city) is best avoided at night. Nonetheless, the city is plagued by opportunistic and petty crime and no area can be considered immune from the risk of crime.

Petty Crime: The largest threat to travellers visiting Buenos Aires will likely be petty crime. Common areas where acts of petty crime have occurred in the past include tourist spots, airports and transportation hubs, and shopping districts. Petty criminals often work in pairs and groups, including with children, where one assailant distracts the victim by asking a question, while another grabs the victim’s bag and runs off. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight. Do not use mobile phones near the doors on public transportation as theft can swiftly snatch and flee. Always leave your valuables in a locked hotel room safe, rather than carry them with you. Travellers should be especially vigilant regarding laptop bags, and avoid putting bags containing valuables on the ground. Similarly, do not leave coats or handbags hanging on the backs of chairs while in restaurants.

Street crime including flash robberies and muggings are chronic in Buenos Aires. Thieves mostly focus on mobile phones, with an average of 193 robberies recorded daily in 2018. Criminals distract victims before quickly stealing valuables. Flash thefts occur mostly during peak hours during week days from 12:00 until 20:00 hours. Most plagued areas include Recoleta, Balvanera, Almagro, Palermo, Villa Lugano as well as Flores, Caballito, Belgrano, San Nicolás (Microcentro), Barracas and Constitución. Criminals also operate along busy and well-frequented avenidas of Rivadavia, Cabildo, Santa Fe, 9 de Julio and Corrientes as well as along Florida's pedestrian zone.

Violent Crime: There has been a slow but steady increase in muggings and armed robbery in the Buenos Aires city centre and the neighbourhoods of Palermo, Recoleta, San Telmo, Constitución and La Boca. This increase is currently being attributed to a rise in drug use, especially crack cocaine. Street crimes in the San Telmo, Puerto Madero, La Boca, Plaza San Martin, Avenida 9 de Julio, Florida Street, Tigre and Ezeiza International Airport areas are common. San Telmo, Palermo and La Boca and the Gran Buenos Aires area (Vicente López, Olivos, Martinez, Acassuso, San Isidro and towards the north of Buenos Aires city) is very dangerous at night and should be avoided; motorists often do not stop at traffic lights where the majority of assaults occur. The majority of homicides took place in Retiro, Villa Lugano, Flores and Constitutión neighbourhoods, according to the 2018 Criminal Statistics Report.

Low-income neighbourhoods: Shanty towns known as Villas miserias are low-income urban settlements typically plagued by the drug trade, turf-wars between criminal groups, drug abuse and other criminal activity. There are at least 14 villas and 24 other similar settlements in the city with estimated population of 275,000. International narco-trafficking groups operate in these areas with silent consent from police authorities. In April 2016 major security operation targeted dozens of drug houses across Villa 31 and Villa 31 bis - one of the most dangerous and biggest villas miserias signalling new efforts of the administration of President Mauricio Macri to tackle flourishing narco-trafficking in the city. Visitors should be cautious not to accidentally wander into these neighbourhoods as they risk being robbed, kidnapped or subject to accidental bodily harm. Villa 31 and Villa 31 bis are located between Retiro's train station and bus terminal. Be extra caution when walking around this transportation hub, day and night. Another notoriously dangerous villa is 1-11-14, dominated by Paraguayan 'Sanpedranos' drug-traffickers, located north of the San Lorenzo football stadium in Nueva Pompeya district. Other more remote villas that should be avoided including Villa 15 (Ciudad Oculta), Villa 20 - located in suburban southwestern districts of Villa Soldati, Mataderos and Villa Lugano. Moreover, Villa 21, Villa 24 and Villa Zabaleta are other large slum areas lying along the Matanza River south of the Buenos Aires Belgrano Sur Line railway station between Barracas, Parque Patricios and Nueva Pompeya districts.

Low-income areas with smaller pockets of violent neighbourhoods spread along the edges of the city proper out of the reach of regular visitors. However, other areas to avoid include Villa La Cava in San Isidro district, a small villa right north of the Federico Lacroze train station in Chacarita district and the Presidente Perón area in Saavedra in the north of the city as well as the southern port areas along the Matanza River.

Kidnapping: Although not uncommon, long-term abductions are less frequent than 'express kidnapping' for monetary gains in Argentina. Occurring predominately in Buenos Aires and its suburbs, express kidnappings - short-term abductions aimed at quickly extracting cash or other valuables from the victim - target people from all levels of society as well as foreign nationals and tourists. Victims often report having been assaulted, though fatalities are rare. Victims are commonly kidnapped outside banks or automated teller machines (ATMs) and forced to withdraw additional money while in the kidnappers' custody. They are often released within hours or on the same day after making one or even multiple payments. Criminals are also known to disguise themselves as police officers by wearing a full uniform or to pose as taxi drivers.

Protests and Demonstrations: Protests and demonstrations are common in Buenos Aires and typically take place in the city's Plaza de Mayo and Congreso areas as well as around Obelisco. Demonstrations often cause roadblocks and disrupt traffic, and are usually non-violent. Occasionally, however, clashes with police and property vandalism will occur. It is best to avoid large public protests by mapping alternate travel routes.

Sports-related Riots: Violence associated with football has always been pronounced in Argentina. At least 305 people have been killed in football-related violence since the league began in the 1930s, and the problem has worsened - 137 of those deaths have occurred in the last 20 years. In recent seasons, matches have been postponed, the league suspended, and teams banned from their own grounds as a result of violence perpetrated by barra bravas (hooligans, or more literally fierce gangs). These gangs are said to be linked to club officials, politicians, and the police, and may be armed with knives and guns. As a general rule, visitors should avoid matches between major rivals, especially those between the Boca Juniors and River Plate clubs at 'La Bombonera' stadium (Estadio Alberto J. Armando) in La Boca area and at 'El Monumental' stadium (Estadio Monumental Antonio Vespucio Liberti) in Belgrano district. When attending matches, try seating close to an exit in case violent unrest breaks out.

Terrorism: Although the incidence of terrorism is low in Argentina, Buenos Aires does have a history of terrorist attacks, most of which targeted the Jewish population at the Israeli Embassy and the AMIA community centre in the 1990s. Since then, explosions in the capital have been blamed on anti-globalisation groups and have mainly targeted foreign banks. Anonymous telephonic bomb threats have also triggered investigations and evacuations at railway stations, banks and public buildings. In 2013, a homemade bomb detonated outside of a social security office after hours in Buenos Aires, causing no casualties. In 2012, three bomb attacks were recorded and targeted the European Union Offices, the Federal Department of Corrections, a theatre where former Colombian President Álvaro Uribe was to deliver a lecture and at a municipal office in Greater Buenos Aires.
health:
Medical care and health facilities in Buenos Aires are of a generally high standard and are widely available. Well-trained personnel are readily available in hospitals, many of whom have studied abroad, and some health professionals have English speaking skills. Public hospitals provide emergency and non-emergency services without cost, regardless of nationality. However, the quality of non-emergency care in public hospitals is not comparable to that in private hospitals. Serious medical problems requiring hospitalisation in private facilities can be very expensive as doctors may expect upfront payment prior to the rendering of services. Buenos Aires has a reliable local ambulance service covering the city, although emergency response times may vary. They can be reached by dialling emergency number 911.

Local Hospitals/Clinics

- Hospital Fernández (Public): Cervino 3356, Palermo, Capital Federal; Tel: 4808-2600
- Hospital Alemán: Pueyrredon 1640, Recoleta, Capital Federal; Tel: 4827-7000
- Sanatorio Trinidad: Cervino 4720, Palermo, Capital Federal; Tel: 4127-5500
- British Hospital: Perdriel 74, Centro, Capital Federal; Tel: 4309-6400

Vaccinations and Documentation

Recommended routine vaccinations include: Hepatitis A and B; Typhoid; Measles/Mumps/Rubella (MMR); Diphtheria/Pertussis/Tetanus (DPT); Influenza.

Common Ailments

Dengue Fever: Dengue fever is a viral infection, transmitted by the bite of the Aedes mosquito. Symptoms include a high fever, joint pain and headaches, although severe cases may cause significant falls in blood pressure and/or haemorrhaging, which can be fatal. There are no vaccines or treatments for dengue fever. Travellers are advised to regularly apply insect repellent, ensure they are well covered, and sleep under mosquito netting. Particular caution should be exercised during early morning and late afternoon hours, when the Aedes mosquito is most active. The Aedes, and therefore dengue fever, is most prevalent in urban areas.
calendar:
1 January - New Year Day
Businesses and other services may shut down for the duration of the New Year's celebrations.

1 May – Workers' Day/Labour Day/May Day/Spring Day
Student/labour demonstrations. If the holiday falls on a rest day, it may be observed on the next working day.

9 July – Independence Day
Celebration of the declaration of independence of Argentina from Spanish rule in 1816. Anticipate elevated security measures and localised travel disruptions. Avoid all large public gatherings.

25 December – Christmas Day
Businesses and other services may shut down for the duration of the religious holiday.

Dates vary – Easter
Businesses and other services may shut down for the duration of the religious holiday.

properties.name: Metrobus Stations in Liniers area
properties.description: Metrobus bus stops in suburban areas are a frequent target for thieves and muggers, especially in the Liniers area at the end of the Juan Bautista Justo line. Avoid overt displays of wealth and carry only small amounts of cash. Exercise heightened awareness of surroundings.

properties.name: Nueva Pompeya
properties.description: Nueva Pompeya district hosts Villa 1-11-14, low-income urban settlement (villa miseria) that should be avoided at all times due to increased risk of petty and violent crime, drug trade and abuse, turf-wars between criminal groups and other criminal activity. The district is also frequently targeted by armed robberies (piratería del asfalto) of trucks and vehicles that transport goods. Such attacks occur usually during daylight. The district also hosts San Lorenzo football stadium. Avoid travel to the area, particularly at night, due to increased risk of violent crime and football-related violence.

properties.name: Villa Soldati
properties.description: Villa Soldati hosts low-income urban settlements (villas miseria) that should be avoided at all times due to incresed risk of petty and violent crime, drug trade and abuse, turf-wars between criminal groups and other criminal activity. The district is also frequently targeted by armed robberies (piratería del asfalto) of trucks and vehicles that transport goods. Such attacks occur usually during daylight. Avoid travel to the area, particularly at night, due to increased risk of violent crime.

properties.name: Palermo district and Jorge Newbery Airfield
properties.description: Palermo district is frequently targeted by muggings and armed robberies, including of trucks and vehicles that transport goods (piratería del asfalto). Such attacks occur usually during daylight. The area is very dangerous at night and should be avoided. Jorge Newbery Airfield (AEP/SABE), also located in the district, is always crowded with travellers, with a very high risk of petty crime. Bags should never be left unattended to minimise the risk of pick-pocketing. Only use licensed taxis available outside the Arrivals halls.

properties.name: Flores
properties.description: Petty and violent street crime is prevalent in Flores, both during day and night. The district also has a high rate of homicides and is frequently targeted by armed robberies (piratería del asfalto) of trucks and vehicles that transport goods. Such attacks occur usually during daylight. Travellers should avoid the area at night, and secure their bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip during daylight. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight.

properties.name: Ministro Pistarini International Airport (EZE/SAEZ)
properties.description: Ministro Pistarini International Airport (EZE/SAEZ), also known as Ezeiza International Airport, is always crowded with travellers, with a very high risk of petty crime. Bags should never be left unattended to minimise the risk of pick-pocketing. Only use licensed taxis available outside the Arrivals halls.

properties.name: Recoleta
properties.description: Recoleta is an affluent neighbourhood, but is also a hotspot for violent street crime, both during day and night, including along the busy and well-frequented Avenida Santa Fe. Travellers should secure their bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight. The district also hosts part of Villa 31 and Villa 31 bis, one of the largest and most dangerous low-income urban settlements (villa miseria) that should be avoided at all times due to increased risk of petty and violent crime, drug trade and abuse, turf-wars between criminal groups and other criminal activity.

properties.name: Balvanera
properties.description: Balvanera is a main shopping neighbourhood, but has high incidences of petty and violent street crime, both during day and night. Travellers should secure their bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight. Protests and demonstrations typically take place around the Congress building and the neighbouring Plaza del Congreso. Avoid large public protests by mapping alternate travel routes.

properties.name: Almagro
properties.description: Almagro is among the most plagued areas of petty and violent street crime, both during day and night. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight.

properties.name: Villa Lugano
properties.description: Villa Lugano hosts low-income urban settlements (villas miseria), including Villa 15 and 20, that should be avoided at all times due to increased risk of petty and violent crime, drug trade and abuse, turf-wars between criminal groups and other criminal activity. The district also has a high rate of homicides and its Metrobus bus stops are a frequent target for thieves and muggers along the Southern line.

properties.name: Caballito
properties.description: Caballito has high rates of petty and violent street crime, including along the busy and well-frequented Avenida Rivadavia, both during day and night. Travellers should secure their bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight.

properties.name: Belgrano
properties.description: Belgrano is an affluent neighbourhood, with significant levels of violent street crime, including along the busy and well-frequented Avenida Cabildo, both during day and night. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight. The district also hosts the 'El Monumental' stadium, home to River Plate football club. Avoid travel to the area, particularly at night, due to increased risk of violent crime and football-related violence.

properties.name: San Nicolás
properties.description: San Nicolás (Microcentro,) is the city’s business and performing arts hub, but violent and petty street crimes continue to be reported, including along the busy and well-frequented Avenida 9 de Julio, Avenida Corrientes and the pedestrian street Florida, both during day and night. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight. Protests and demonstrations typically take place around the Obelisco. Avoid large public protests by mapping alternate travel routes.

properties.name: Barracas
properties.description: Barracas is known for high levels of petty and violent street crime, both during day and night. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight. The district also hosts the Villa 21 and 24 low-income urban settlements (villa miseria) that should be avoided at all times due to increased risk of petty and violent crime, drug trade and abuse, turf-wars between criminal groups and other criminal activity.

properties.name: Constitución
properties.description: There have been many reports of petty and violent crime in the district, including around Plaza Constitución railway station, both during day and night. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight.

properties.name: San Telmo
properties.description: Bohemian San Telmo is a tourist hotspot, but the area has a heightened risk of both petty and violent crime and is particularly dangerous at night. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight.

properties.name: La Boca
properties.description: La Boca is a tourist hotspot, with many reports of petty and violent crime. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight. The district also hosts the 'La Bombonera' stadium, home to the Boca Juniors football club. Avoid travel to the area, particularly at night, due to increased risk of violent crime and football-related violence.

properties.name: Retiro
properties.description: Retiro has high incidences of petty and violent crime, both during day and night. Travellers should secure bags with a strap across the chest from the shoulder to the front of the opposite hip. Keep valuables such as mobile phones, jewellery and wallets out of sight. The district also has a high rate of homicide, and hosts part of Villa 31 - one of the most dangerous and biggest low-income urban settlement (villa miseria) - that should be avoided at all times due to increased risk of petty and violent crime, drug trade and abuse, turf-wars between criminal groups and other criminal activity.
